MAIL adds scheduling of triggered video clip, with the familiar 7-day scheduling block, and video clip size (3MB max) and time (15 sec max) limits  FTP adds scheduling, with the familiar 7-day scheduling block, and again video clip size (3MB max) and time (15 sec max) limitsMAINTENANCE differences include:  Added OnScreenDisplay of time, in 6 colors; in upper right corner, niceThe DCS-931L's FTP setup for images is the same as that of the 930 & 932, ... that is, there is NO apparent control of frame rate other than geography (distance to the receiving server). We are ftp'ing images to a remote server (on the opposite coast of the U.S.) at about 2 fps, which is good. FTP'ing to a local computer causes frame rate to rise to 15 fps or greater and that really eats up storage space. We hope that with this camera's greater processing power & memory, D-Link will add specific frame rate control for FTP of images.Another issue is that the myDlink view/control website is NOT giving the live video on Firefox; but it is working on Safari & Chrome. This may (shudder) require a call to DLink tech support. EDIT - after several days, it started working in Firefox ...EDIT 08/21 - we had been seeing strange flashes when real-time viewing (using the JustConnect+ app) - now we've confirmed that frequent bad images are stored on the ftp server. Not a good thing for a security camera - it's going back.

Reviews.Title: Don't Expect Technical Support
Reviews.Author: MightyOak
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because of the remote access to it via MyDlink.com The camera worked fine within my home's WiFi range, but I couldn't sign on to MyDlink.com for remote monitoring. Eight days of "hold" and two Case Numbers issued with their so called "technical support" and I still cannot log into MyDlink. They used to have wonderful support and that's why I always brought D-Link products. Obviously, they have outsourced their support to people with little or no knowledge of the product and total disrespect for you as a customer.I strongly recommend you shop elsewhere. If it weren't for Amazon's great return policy, I would be stuck with something I could not use (remotely).

Reviews.Title: Worst camera software
Reviews.Author: Alexander
Reviews.Content: The hardware is OK but this is probably the worst camera software I've ever seen (I have Logitech Alert and Netgear VueZone).1. You will need to download software to your computer to find and connect your camera to the cloud. (VueZone is connect and done).2. You will need to open a firewall on you computer for the software to be able to find your camera, have to google for that3. Finally, got the account and .... it is JAVA based! So you have to dance with your browsers to get it work.... so far spent 1 hour googling for the solutions ...4. When you setup email notifications from mydlink - the email does not contain image or video! The trick here is to connect to the camera itself, using the local camera address in your network and setup mail notifications there.5. The usability is horrible - to setup "active areas" for the motion detection  you have click many times.6. And at last - I was not able to configure the motion detection so it will not send me false positive emails. Got 2500 emails in 2 days with the same still picture.Obviously, the software is alfa version, need lots of work.

Reviews.Title: Lousy customer service, minimal Mac support, it works-barely
Reviews.Author: Richard L. Garrett
Reviews.Content: I've got four of these cameras, while they DO work, the technical support sends canned responses, the customer forum on mydlink.com is quick to ban any adverse product discussion, and the MAC BETA utility software has been beta since January 2011 and will not allow me to add cameras to mydlink.com. We'll see how the hardware performs but my first impressions are far from favorable. If you are a Macintosh user, beware, you are on your own.9/10/2011: A new Macintosh setup utility is available here: [....]Be persistent with customer service, I FINALLY got past the canned/programmed responses and got help in the form of a new setup wizard.

Reviews.Title: Set up and wifi problems
Reviews.Author: Corey Kaye
Reviews.Content: I purchased this cam specifically for the mydlink.com feature so I could view online from anywhere or on my phone.  The camera went through the entire set up process without a hitch until we reached the step where it connects to mydlink.com, and it would not connect.  Spoke with customer support--they could not determine the cause and issued an RMA.  The replacement camera had exactly the same issue, so I set up port forwarding with a dyndns.com account...and the replacement camera could not pick up my wifi signal in the area I'd like to view (the original camera picked up the signal fine in that location.)  Sent the second camera back and am going to try the Foscam.This might be a great camera IF you can get one that doesn't have setup/connection problems.

Reviews.Title: Terrible wireless performance
Reviews.Author: Paul Anderson
Reviews.Content: I have owned and been very happy with two DCS-920's for the past year or so. One of them recently stopped working, so I decided to replace it with the DCS-930L. The 920 has an external WiFi antenna, and the 930L does not, so I was interested to see how strong the signal would be on the new camera.I received it and connected it to my D-Link DIR-628 wireless router and immediately noticed that the 930L's Signal(%) reading was about 30% and the transmitted image was very jerky - about one image every 2-3 seconds with complete freezes of 4-5 seconds. My 920, connected to the same router with the same image quality and size settings was showing 100% signal and streaming fluid video.  The 920, by the way, was also located twice as far from the router as the 930L. I actually moved the router so that it was within 10 feet of the 930L with a clear line of sight - and that only improved the Signal(%) value to about 60%.I called D-Link support and they had me upgrade the firmware for the 930L. That didn't improve things, so they told me it must be a hardware problem and gave me a support reference number and told me to return it. Amazon quickly shipped a new one which just arrived this afternoon. I set it up with the same D-Link router and am seeing exactly the same poor performance.So now I'll be returning two units instead of one. I'm very disappointed that D-Link would release a product that's so obviously broken. Perhaps if they'd added an external antenna, this would be a wireless video camera instead of a wireless camera that is only capable of "streaming" one picture every couple of seconds.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, great price
Reviews.Author: LeJean Dennis
Reviews.Content: I would highly recommend this camera, it works great. We have it set up in our chicken coop which is approx. 75 yards from our house. We can monitor their environment for temp, humidity and their behavior from anywhere, day or night with the added night vision capabilities (We have our thermometer in view of the camera also). We are going to order another one for the chicken run so we can keep an eye out for predators and double check ourselves to make sure the automatic door is shut at night and opening in the morning etc. We go down there a lot and spend time with them (they are very entertaining) but this just gives us an added piece of mind. Great value. Thank you!

Reviews.Title: Difficult to setup motion sensing only now works with the last update
Reviews.Author: Sandy
Reviews.Content: Bought this 3+ months ago.  Set-up was buggy and not for the technically illiterate.  The unit has required multiple cumbersome and unclear firmware updates.  At one point had to completely reset the unit and start all the updates over.  However, I'm happy to report with the last firmware update 1.11 the motion detection now works as advertised. (It did not prior) The free phone app does work and is a good compliment.  I'm hoping it remains stable and and does its job from here forward.

Reviews.Title: Not an easy set up on a Mac running Mavericks
Reviews.Author: L.Gildart
Reviews.Content: Compared to a similar camera made by Belkin, setting up the D-Link was kind of a pain.  Not as much of a pain as setting up a Foscam F18918W - where you get directed to a third party domain name provider and get to learn the joys of port forwarding - but a relative hassle.For the Belkin, I opened the box, plugged into my router, ran a set up program that took less than five minutes, downloaded an app, and I was up and running.  While this is a very similar product in both look and function, it took over an hour - and two ethernet cables - to set it up.  There is no Mac software on the installation cd.  The box states that a Windows pc is required, but the website has a Mac download available.  You have to scroll through the product photos, which aren't in alphanumeric order.  Just keep looking until you find the DCS-930L - AFTER the 931L and the 932L and the 934L.  Have faith.  Keep going.  It's there.Once you get the program installed, it takes very little time to *find* the camera and teach it to log into your wireless network.  And then you are back to the website to set up your account and view your camera.  Except you are on a Mac, and the viewer requires you to install the Java Runtime Environment.  JRE is a big old security vulnerability on Macs.  So much so that Apple advises against using it.  Mavericks lets you turn it on case by case - and, by default, it will ask you every time before running it.  If you are on an OS below Mavericks, check the googles for setting your preferences so that you're not running JRE all the time.Okay, so now you've got JRE going, and the first thing the program tells you is that you have to update your firmware AND you need to have the camera AND your computer ethernet-jacked right into your router.  LOLWUT?  I'm lucky.  I am on a laptop, and I have an extra ethernet cable and an empty port.  So, I did that, and there I was, up and running, about an hour, hour and a half, thereabouts, after I started.Image quality is pretty good - not great.  Audio is okay.  The settings are very customizable.  But the wifi receiver is very weak, and that limits the usefulness of this product.

Reviews.Title: great camera
Reviews.Author: Sonia Deluna "cakes"
Reviews.Content: very easy to set up --- set up using the app on my iPad - quality of the picture in complete darkness is awesome. it does have a pretty limited viewing field - also the power cord to this is pretty short

Reviews.Title: Terribly Unreliable
Reviews.Author: RYAN M ZINK
Reviews.Content: I have six Dlink cameras setup and rarely are all of the up and running at the same time.  They like to randomly go offline for hours to days at a time.  This unreliability is unacceptable in a security camera.  I would not recommend this product line to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Okay camera for monitoring room with normal room light
Reviews.Author: Numb3rTech "Sonya Ann"
Reviews.Content: Camera does okay monitoring outside during daylight or with strong regular flood lights.  It also does okay in the house monitoring as long as there is plenty of normal light.I do not recommend these cameras since they do not allow viewing using external IR lights.  I gave them 2 stars for daylight type applications only.These cameras are poor for low light situations.  I purchased 3 for testing and have taken them off.  I did not keep the boxes and can not return them.  I will not purchase or use this type of IP camera.

Reviews.Title: Works Great
Reviews.Author: CanDoTina
Reviews.Content: I ordered this with hopes that I could check in on my place while getting home improvements done on my home while I am at work and I am very impressed with this little gadget.  Didn't take me any time to set it up, and I have the app on my phone and I can check in on things with just a click of a tab and the video is live stream.  I was a little concerned with all the mixed reviews on the D-Link DCS-930L - but for me, it worked awesome for my little home improvement project and now since my home improvement project is over, I can check in on my little furry friend Oscar and see what he is up to during the day. :)I just wanted to say that I have definitely gotten my value from this product.  Thank you.

Reviews.Title: Easy to install
Reviews.Author: Andrew Leake
Reviews.Content: Easy to install, took less than 5 minutes.  Great iPhone app to check the camera.  The quality of image is just OK, but for the price, I was very surprised.  Would highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: An excellent, inexpensive solution
Reviews.Author: Steve
Reviews.Content: This camera has worked flawlessly since I installed it about a month ago.  The software provides only basic functionality but it does the job.  You can access the camera using the device's own interface, from the web using mydlink.com, or from the web using a phone app.  The device interface can be accessed from your PC or wirelessly and gives you a ton of settings.  The phone app (mydlink lite) lets you view through your camera and change a few very basic settings:  Sound Detection (on/off), Motion Detection (on/off), Extender Mode (on/off).  mydink.com is similar but gives you a few more options that the phone app.  The functionality between the three apps overlap and how they cooperate (or don't) is a mystery to me and perhaps also to dlink support.  Speaking of support, it's not bad.  I've been able to reach dlink support very easily and have had many of my questions answered, not thoroughly, but with some satisfaction.  However the agents often can't understand your questions either because of their knowledge level and/or because of language issues.  Even if they understand your question, they often recite the answer off of some literature that you've already read yourself (and needed more in-depth information... which is why you called in the first place!).  In any case, you can expect competent support but don't expect any in-depth explanations.

Reviews.Title: Do it.
Reviews.Author: Unobfuscated
Reviews.Content: Most importantly, it was easy to setup, worked without substantial research or customer support contact, and performed as described.  Functionality is more limited that other similar devices, but priced appropriately (i.e., lower).  A good starter/basic camera, after having returned another (different make/model) that I was unable to configure.

Reviews.Title: D-Link DCS-930L Network Cam
Reviews.Author: D. Pappas "DenVette"
Reviews.Content: Liked the write ups on this cam, it works very well.  You can set it for motion when you are away and it will alert your phone, iPad or computer.  Only things is to set the sensitivity 50% or lower or you will get notifications all the time.good unit and set-up was  a breeze.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Just a guy
Reviews.Content: I have four of these around my house.  The cameras are easy to configure on my network and they give a nice picture.  One star deduction because the sound is terrible - lots of background static.  Also, the base cannot be removed - it doesn't have a standard tripod mount in the back - which is odd.The mydlink iphone app is only OK.  IP Cam Viewer is much better.

Reviews.Title: Very good for the price
Reviews.Author: JJ
Reviews.Content: The cam works, the software works, everithing works :)The software has many options, to use with diferent internet speeds.For example, when I installed it, we have slow internet, so I configured a slow FPS, low quality jpgs and it works fine.And it stylish if you want to install it in a viewable area.Good product.

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: laura jean kiser
Reviews.Content: I can be at work and check on my animals in the house also sends me an email due to motion. Love it

Reviews.Title: Amazing!
Reviews.Author: Shaun
Reviews.Content: This product is very useful and makes life easier. It surpassed my expectations and notifies me anytime motion is detected. I mounted it to the wall for a better view with command strips and it works great. I only wish the power cable was longer. I highly recommend this product.

Reviews.Title: Steep learning curve but so far they work.....
Reviews.Author: Christopher Anderson "Splnkr"
Reviews.Content: Whew!  After a crash course in IP addresses, MAC's, SSID's, routers, WPS, and a lot of cursing and head slapping, I think I have my five camera home security system up and running.Initially bought three of the DCS-931L's, then accidentally bought two of the older DCS-930L's. They are for all intents and purposes the same in functionality, though I initially found the 931L's software easier to use. Stick with 931's.At first I had pretty good luck setting these cameras up with my old Buffalo Tech router. You hard wire them first, run the setup wizard (which you have to download as a zip file and is not real easy to get going), then you can WPS the cameras wirelessly. Move them and install anyplace. Range is surprisingly good.The MyDlink was ok to work with. This is the online portal to your cameras. The smartphone app counterpart was pretty good at sending me notifications of movement--at first. Then, suddenly, I started losing feeds from the cameras.  Pretty soon every one was dead. Must have uninstalled and reinstalled them a dozen times. And then I lost home WIFI. So, I assumed it was a bad router.  What luck.  So, I ordered a D-Link 855 model, more than anything because of "zero configuration" with their cameras.Installed the new router and everything seemed fine.  Then the same thing started happening. I could wirelessly configure the cameras straight from the router, but the IP addresses of the cameras were being assigned to other devices, and this caused all sorts of problems.  I kept uninstalling and reinstalling, trying to reserve IP addresses in the router...  Then I'd get them working only to find them slowly dropping out again. It seems to help to reserve the IP addresses of your other devices first, then install the cameras.I finally came to the conclusion that the way to install them is first to wirelessly WPS them from the router to the camera. Then I'd go into D-ViewCam (this is their proprietary PC program you use to record motion to your drive as evidence of trespass or burglary). In D-ViewCam I would manually "insert" the camera in the settings area using the IP address assigned by the router. Then I'd hop over to MyDlink and find the camera via "zero config" and set it up there online. That seemed to eliminate lost feeds, and for several days it has run with no problem. Most of the time the software couldn't "find" the camera during a scan, so I opted to key them in manually. It's easy. On a few of the cameras they still would not "connect". But if I walked away for a few hours, bingo!  It was as if it just took some time for the software to recognize them. One other thing, you need D-ViewCam to change the camera resolutions. I could not do this in MyDlink.There are a few quirks still.  MyDlink app has stopped giving me motion alerts. I can define areas of the feed to detect motion in D-ViewCam, but no longer in MyDlink web. It just shows a black screen. It will let you define a zone, but since you can't see what the image is it is of little use. I think this is why I'm not getting alerts via the app.  I don't know what happened and am looking into this. But the D-ViewCam does record motion to my hard drive. By the way, I am using a USB external drive hidden in the basement in case someone steals my computer!Anyway, to sum up, the cameras do work.  Picture quality is good enough to make out faces and cars coming up the drive.  I can keep an eye on the dogs quite easily using the smartphone app, though the latter does require a good strong fast connection. Otherwise, it just times out. I really like the D-Link routers.  Coming from years of the Buffalo Tech, they are much easier to configure with their outstanding web based portal. Five stars there. And setting up the cameras is nice because you don't have to use the MyDlink software, which I found buggy and hard to install, or a LAN cable.I have two cameras inside, three outside under the eaves, and one out in my carport. I have the repeaters on the 931's active, but even when they are off the range to other cameras straight from the router is good (about three walls, one brick, and 70 feet total). I plan on adding more cameras, including the IR versions for dark areas. So far the cameras have held up outside in below freezing temps and high humidity. They stand out like a sore thumb, but I figure if they get stolen it's too late. The video has already been captured. Because of this and their relative low cost, I have not taken measures to hide them. Hell, I want the thieves to put their faces in them so I get a close view!It has been a frustrating two weeks messing with these buggers. But once I got the flow down, I am happy.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Evan Galatz
Reviews.Content: I have a ton of these cameras and I absolutely love it.I have them set up around my house and in my vacation house. Its great to be able to check up on the place when I am not at home. Also if I have a contractor they know I can be watching them at any time so I think it keeps them on their toes.I have even used the one pointing at my driveway to see who is ringing the doorbell at 6am while I am still in bed.Its definitely worth the investment, you won't regret it!

Reviews.Title: Static
Reviews.Author: LEGEND600 "LEGEND600"
Reviews.Content: What is up with the static and scratching sounds when audio is turned on?  Very annoying had to turn the audio off.  I wonder if D- Link Systems have their quality people working on this?  They really should if they want this product to do well.

Reviews.Title: Low cost security option
Reviews.Author: Michael A. Puchel
Reviews.Content: I purchased two DCS930s for my home.  Set up took less than 10 minutes.  Picture quality is not the best and definitely not for low lighting applications. After downloading Dlink light app I can see pictures on any of my computers including Iphone and I pad.  A good buy if picture quality and lighting are not a requirement

Reviews.Title: Awesome product
Reviews.Author: tabatha l linden
Reviews.Content: Good product however you really need to figure out the hook up.  You will probably end up calling tech support at least once or twice.  I ordered three cameras and I got one to work.  I think its operator error...stay tune

Reviews.Title: Best Value IP Camera
Reviews.Author: Brian's Reviews
Reviews.Content: I have had various IP cameras over the last 5-10 years but this is by far the best value, the easiest to setup, and the most versatile with mobile application support.  My previous cameras did not have a mobile app and required PC only to view.  This is such a massive improvement that I switched my entire house to these cameras.  To be clear I know that I can spend a lot more for a little bit sharper cameras but these are more than sufficient to allow me to check on my house and record for basic security on top of my security system.  Once again these provide the best value or bang for your buck.

Reviews.Title: Worked right out of the box
Reviews.Author: Ming "Ming"
Reviews.Content: I wasn't able to activate the camera over my wifi network, but had to plug it into the router to set up. But after that it has worked flawlessly on the wifi.

Reviews.Title: Can't access camera with cell phone's data plan but a decent security camera
Reviews.Author: The Tech Fanatic "The Tech Fanatic"
Reviews.Content: I found this camera on sale at Best Buy for basically sixty bucks and I always wanted one. It does a basic job.The cons:1. Very short cord. You will have to situate it close to an outlet unless you don't mind running an extension cord.2. The instruction manual is not very intuitive and the installation process from the website is not very intuitive. I can see that a lot of negative reviews about this camera coming from this. They probably used the wrong software as there are several models to choose from and the box has what appears to be a model number but it is not. The model number is on the cover of the manual and I can see a lot of people not reading the booklet and just going straight to the installation wizard. I made that mistake myself as I was so eager to get it going. I ended up choosing the wrong software and as a result it didn't work.3. This camera is made of a cheap flimsy plastic and so you must place it where it will not get banged around. Installing to a wall can be a risky undertaking as you will have to snap open the base using a screwdriver.4. The biggest con for this IP camera is that you cannot view with your camera on your phone's 3G or 4G. You have to connect to your network at home in order to use it. I used the Dlink Lite app for this purpose. It's a wonderful app but misses the whole point about taking your app outside of your home.5. Does not work with Firefox or Opera. You need to use Windows Internet Explorer.6. Requires Java installation which is not something that you would normally want installed on your computer due to some security issues.7. Constantly disconnects.The pros:1. Great picture quality. Of course, it is not DVD quality. It is webcam quality.2. Has adjustable sensitivity for movement detection. You can have it watch only a certain area or the whole picture frame.3. Sends an email to you if it detects motion or sound. You can adjust the sound sensitivity, too. It is able to send you an image or images when it detects motion but you will need to know how to set it up.4. It is wireless so you can place it anywhere where there is an electrical outlet.5. Has a range extender that will enhance the range of your wireless network to allow the camera to be placed further away from the router.6. It is pretty small.7. Has night vision capability. I was amazed at the image I got from a dark room.8. Has the option to allow you to choose wired connection.There is one review that gives out misinformation. And that review states that you should sign up for an account before installing this software. Well, you cannot sign up outside of the installation. You see, you need to do the installation in order to sign up.This camera does a very basic job. If you are looking to simply view a room or family while away, this will do the job if the camera does not disconnect on you. If you are looking for the ability to carry an app with you to view the images, then this is not the one to get. I could not get it to stream any image via a cell phone data line. But, if you are only looking to monitor a room from within the home and not while away, this will do the job. Further, it does not support micro SD card so it cannot record images without a network drive. If you have some tech know-how, this should be no problem installing. If you are not tech savvy, you may have some difficulties. In either case, if you are patient, you should be able to install this product. One advice: use the manual wireless set up instead of the sync connection with the router. That did not work at all with my router.Update:I have been using the camera now for about a month now and have found another issue that I should share with others. The camera's motion sensitivity setting is basically useless as it detects the slightest movements such as those of a curtain or atmospheric light change. I had set it at the lowest sensitivity setting and selected only a small area of the frame. That results in constant emails from the camera. Be ready to receive tons of emails with constant detection of movement. The sound detection was not as bad, though. Either I got a bad camera or there is some serious problems with the motion detection feature. Another thing that I have discovered is that the Dlink Lite app which was pretty useless ran in the background using up resources. I finally uninstalled this useless app.

Reviews.Title: Does what we wanted it to.
Reviews.Author: Fatsnaps
Reviews.Content: For what we paid for it, it's been excellent.  We use it to keep and eye on our children when not on the same floor in the house.  The video quality isn't HD by any means, but it's adequate for what we need.  I can view the camera from my iPhone anywhere.  Easy setup, no problems.If you want a camera that will work well in low light or can be controlled remotely (for panning), this isn't what you want.  If you want a cheap camera you can throw in the corner of a room to check out your dog when you're at work, don't hesitate to pick this up.  Seems to be best solution for the money.

Reviews.Title: Won't connect to wireless network
Reviews.Author: Scott D
Reviews.Content: I was unable to get it to connect to my wireless network (2wire 2701).  I spent 1.5 hours on the phone with tech support and they could not get it to connect.  When they wanted the password to my router so they could do remotely the same things we had been doing over the phone I said enough.  Even if I could have gotten it to connect, I am not sure how useful it would have been.  The camera was 20 feets from the wireless router, no walls and when I did a site survey during installation and it found my wireless network, it said signal strength was 34%.  When we updated the firmware I noticed that the orignal firmware was from 2010-8-10, over three years old.  I noticed in the manual that if your router doesn't support UPnP the the installation wizard will not work (mine doesn't support it).  My son-in-law purchased a higher end D-link camera and he has had the exact same problem, won't connect to wireless network.  I think I am going analog.

Reviews.Title: Very nice little camera to get your feet wet
Reviews.Author: D. Booth "Fighting Back One Gadget At A Time"
Reviews.Content: It's November and I've been using this camera since May. I wanted to set up several cameras to watch different areas in my home when I'm not there. This is a day only, 1-way audio(I can hear what is in the area of the camera but can't talk to anyone there), there is no pan and tilt. It works wirelessly for the signal but yes, you have to have a wire to plug in to a power outlet. You also have to use the provided ethernet cable and connect it to your wireless router to do the initial set up. When I first opened the box, there was a CD that was clearly marked "begin here". I put it in the drive on my computer and followed the direction and this little puppy was up and running wirelessly in no time. I could then unplug it and move it room to room and each time it was still communicating wirelessly. If you do unplug it and you want it to have the right time, you do have to rest the new time but that is pretty easy and can be done wirelessly. Since this was my first dlink camera, the set up took me through setting up my mydlink account. This is free and you log in to it to watch your camera when you are away from home. Your computers can be off while your gone but your modem(I'm on DSL) and wireless router need to be working. I set this up to send  6 pictures to my email on any detected motion so I can also see snapshots of things that may have happened when I wasn't watching via the mydlink website. You can also use the Dlink lite free application to watch the video feed on a Kindle HD. Once I was happy with this camera I mounted it on a wall in my home office and it detects anyone that enters the office. This was mounted several months ago and I haven't had to do anything to it. I can watch the office from anywhere at anytime and I can check emailed images to see anything I may have missed. After this camera, I thought I would move up to a day/night, pan and tilt camera and bought a dcs5010L which I have found requires a lot more attention and has a few issues. However the 5010L made me realize how nice this little camera was for the price. I do wish it had the day/night feature but I don't find the pan/tilt that useful on the other camera for my current use. If you just want a simple camera to look at one specific lighted area and to detect motion, this is a good camera. I look at it at as a good camera to start with. I have plans for a few more of these and one or two with additional features for specific jobs.

Reviews.Title: Tired of beta testing for Dlink
Reviews.Author: Dave
Reviews.Content: I've used the 930Ls and have had OK success with them.  This one is not ready for prime-time yet.  On mine, I setup motion detection to send video clips to my email address.  It sends 20-30 false positive videos a day.  Their tech support is, and always has been lazy (standard answers) and slow, if they ever respond.  They told me to download the most current version of the ROM.  It asks for an unknown password on certain browsers.  Finally downloaded the file and the driver is from April (not July as the web page reports).  They don't even have the most current drivers.  They pointed me to another site which showed a Sept version but it was the July version.  They told me to re-flash the ROM.  No good either.  I'm returning it.  Dlink likes to have their customers alpha and beta test their products.

Reviews.Title: WiFi feature doesn't work, otherwise OK
Reviews.Author: Bill Guenthner "Bill G"
Reviews.Content: I have purchased 5 D-Link cameras including this one. This model was the least expensive and is also the worst by a wide margin. It  won't connect with WPS and must be set up manually and then it simply will not stay connected over wi-fi for more than a few minutes. Otherwise it works as advertised as long as it's connected to the router with an ethernet cable.

Reviews.Title: Good product, easy to install
Reviews.Author: CAVA
Reviews.Content: The D-Link DCS-930L is a camera you can easily connect to your home WiFi network for recording or remote monitoring.  The integration with the MyDlink service is excelent and easy to use and you can start to monitor your camera via WEB or using a mobile device in minutes. The motion detection with notification to the EMail works fine but I had to adjust the sensitivity to avoid the activation by shadows or the wind.  It sends 6 images, 3 of before and 3 of after the motion was detected but if the subject is moving too fast, the camera will miss it.If you need to record video to a PC or NAS, you need a PC always on and running an additional application.  The camera can save still images each second to a NAS using the FTP protocol without using a computer but it cannot record video by itself. The 930L has good image with good light conditions but it won't work if it is too dark so I am buying the 932L for my backyard.I connected this camera to a Netgear WNDR3400v2 router and it works fine, I have not been able to use the FTP functionality since the Netgear has a weird implementation of the protocol and it delivers a 230 message type when connected instead of a 220 message, so the camera thinks it is not connected. I sent a note to Netgear and I will update this post if they answer.

Reviews.Title: BEST Security/Survailance out there for cost/ease
Reviews.Author: Chad Gilezan
Reviews.Content: Wanted something in-expensive to monitor when people leave and come to my house since I have out of town guests all of the time.  This has exceeded my expectations.  It's very inexpensive, has live feed with audio, has software that can send you an email when motion is dectected (you can even pick the section of the frame to detect motion), phone app to show feed as well, and ALL FREE after you buy the camera.  Better than any security system I've seen when it comes to features and price.  Uses of this are endedless!

Reviews.Title: Good for what I wanted
Reviews.Author: Jim
Reviews.Content: I have been wanting a security camera setup for some time being as how I live in the not of best neighborhoods. I did not need night vision (at least for now) as the two areas I wanted to monitor have lights on timers. So in comes the DCS-930LGreat size and versatility in mounting. I have one hanging on a wall and one hanging from the base part at the top of a set of miniblinds looking out a window. By having a curtain over the window and turning off the LED in settings, I do not get any glare from the window itself.To help with mounting, there is a removable ring on the base plate so you can place screws right through the plate.Able to send an email with motion detection. You get 3 frames before detection and 3 frames after. You are able to set a sensitivity level as well as which sections of the image to activate from. You can also do a time out after first detection before it emails again. Something I should have done when my second floor neighbors were moving in. Setting up the email is a chore, you need the various settings. I had issues with setting up my @live address so I made a @gmail one. Settings are easy to find on search engines. You may not want to have your primary email receive the notifications if there will be a lot of detections. Those emails can fill up your inbox pretty fast.Able to ftp to local storage. I got one of those new WD My Cloud 2TB drives. I set up a user for security and a folder for the camera. The settings page for the ftp (and everything else for that matter) are decent but while giving you lots of control, there is a learning curve on the advanced page. To help others: Host: (whatever the ip is for the NAS, 192.168.x.x) Port: 21 (usually), Name / Password: these are whatever your NAS has for access, I initially had these blank but camera was happier with an actual log-in. Path: Here is the one I had issues with. MY path for MY NAS is //Security/FrontCamera where "Security" is the user and FrontCamera the directory I made in that user folder. I saw some indications on the dlink forums that the exact method of the paths / or \ may be interchangeable so if one slash ain't working slash it the other. Options for storage for ftp are:AlwaysSet days and timesMotion (no time out)1,2,3 frames per secondx (your choice) seconds per frameImage Quality is decent for what I paid. HD this is not. However, in proper lighting I can see well enough to make out faces. At night time I have some interference in the signal shown by horizontal lines. This is probably 60 cycle interference from the fluorescent bulbs in the nearby security lights. There is an option to go between 50 and 60 Hz but I did not see a difference. It is not that big of a issue with my setup.DLink Brand. Now that I have a dlink cloud account for this and am able to view the live feeds through the web on their site and a free android application, I will probably stick to dlink moving forward when I get a IR cam for my driveway. I see no reason to change it up at this point.Anything ElseSetup was a headache when I tried to set everything myself. I finally gave up and used the WPS button. That was much easier. The cord is pretty short but was able to pass it through a window (and still close it) onto my porch for placement of one of the cameras. The microphone is able to be disabled, which is a good thing since the other camera is mounted in a bedroom. Be aware of all laws regarding recording in your locale. For instance, in my state audio recording without permission is illegal, video recording when there is no expectation of privacy without permission is not illegal.

Reviews.Title: Great if it works - but it doesn't
Reviews.Author: Stubborn Dutchman
Reviews.Content: I am looking for a decent, low-cost Surveillance Camera for a vacation home that would notify me in the event of an intrusion. I've had this camera for a while, but never used it because I could never get the wireless to work; would not recognize any SSID.Since I plan on using ethernet anyway (I don't trust wifi for continuous dependable service) Thought I'd give the DCS-930L another try.Setup for motion detection and email alert is fairly straighforward, and it works great sometimes.There's the rub - sometimes. What's more, usually not!If I have an intruder, I want to know every time, not sometimes.This is a so-so low resolution network security camera, but don't waste your time and money if you're wanting anything reliable beyond that.

Reviews.Title: Ease of Plug N Play hides advanced features
Reviews.Author: J. Sikes "zoinkster"
Reviews.Content: You won't be making award winning digital shorts with this camera.  But it handles low light ok.  The video sometimes has lines in it.  But for security, it does it's job for me.The myDlink software is great.  It's a simple setup and you can view your camera from anywhere.It hides some excellent features tho, that you can only get to by connecting to the IP address of the camera and using the "old" administrator interface:Two of the big ones for me:Motion DetectionEmails sent when Motion Detection Sensors go offI'm glad they left it as an "advanced user" option (it existed on older options as the default interface).

Reviews.Title: My link
Reviews.Author: Inger Turner
Reviews.Content: Camera to small, picture not clear, and too much static when listening to the audio. Therefore, i would not recommend this camera to family or friends.

Reviews.Title: Wireless can be very difficult to connect.
Reviews.Author: Jackson
Reviews.Content: Could not get this to connect to my wireless router; tried with three different computers (2 pcs and 1 mac), no luck.  Four hours later, still no luck.Gave up and purchased a new wireless router with WPA and the camera finally connected.

Reviews.Title: WIRELESS DOES NOT WORK
Reviews.Author: yorkiemom
Reviews.Content: Very disappointed. After months of trying to get the wireless feature to work I decided to get a different device.  If you have a MAC you have to download software that is not on the disk.  This is definately not SIMPLE to set up unless you are familiar with IP addresses and all.  I wanted something I could plug in and have it walk you through setting it up.  It does not do that.  I agree with other reviewers that tech support has no clue.  If they sell something as wireless they should support getting it set up without having to pay an extra "premium" amount to simply get their product to work as advertised.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera Once You Get Past Setup
Reviews.Author: D. Beckman
Reviews.Content: I work in IT for a living, and for most devices like this I immediately bypass whatever setup CD came with the product and just configure the device from its default web page. You can do that with this device (over Ethernet), but if you want to use their smart phone app, you'll end up having to start from scratch and use their setup anyway -- that's the only way to create the Dlink account that you need to use their phone app. Also, I had problems getting it to connect over WiFi. Eventually I figured out that the camera didn't like my Wifi network's password, because it had a space in it. (Mind you, everything else on the network worked fine with this password.) So I had to remove the space from the WiFi password, and of course re-configure every other WiFi device. Annoying, but it's been working fine ever since.Once setup, I like the camera. I use it to keep an eye on our dog. I shared the address with lots of family, and now I can't even disconnect the camera without getting complaints about the "puppy cam" being down. So, initial setup can be a pain, but I would get it again.

Reviews.Title: Not so Wireless...
Reviews.Author: H Siefers
Reviews.Content: I ordered 2 of these and they are both going back today.  The installation seems to be easy, right up until I get to the part where I try to connect the cameras to the Wifi.  Neither of the units would connect to my Wifi, so I tried at 2 of my neighbor's houses with the same problem.  When you try and enter in the Wifi password the units fail to connect.  I will say that they worked great when connected to a Lan line and the my-Dlink website was easy to log into and view. But I ordered them because of their wireless capabilities which do not work.  I emailed tech support and did not get a response after 5 days.  When I called the 1-800 # to get customer support I found out that I had to provide a credit card # as it was not a free service with no indication of the billing rate... Um WHAT?After several hours of wasted time and money, I can't say that I would purchase from Dlink again, even a newer more expensive model based upon what I experienced with their customer service.

Reviews.Title: Great for window locations
Reviews.Author: George J. Novak
Reviews.Content: Perfect slim size for window ledge installs. East to connect and setup. Avoid the D-Link software and terrible My Link website and just use the webpage generated by the camera. I wish this was available in grey/black as you can get glare bounce from the white camera body. Some issues using the hardwired Ethernet port, but this is mainly designed as a wifi unit.

Reviews.Title: Not many features
Reviews.Author: Louis F.
Reviews.Content: I suppose I didn't do my research.  No panning capabilities, viewing on the internet the image is too small.  Never did figure out how to set up two cameras wirelessly on my network.  Planning on returning them.

Reviews.Title: Works great
Reviews.Author: Russell
Reviews.Content: This works great for the price but later I bought the 932l which has infrared. I would recommend the 932l for the simple fact it will work in the dark.

Reviews.Title: You get what you pay for.
Reviews.Author: Scott Davis "ScottInHawaii"
Reviews.Content: This camera works fine except the constant audio static and popping, which seems worse in the DLink app on my phone and tablet. I'm only using it for fun, nothing serious so it's not that big of a deal. Turning the volume to a lower lever, like 30, in the setup helps. Down at 10 the static ones away, but the sound also cuts in and out a bit.

Reviews.Title: DCS-930L Great picture in bright light; terrible picture in low light.
Reviews.Author: MammonLord
Reviews.Content: I hate it when Amazon mixes reviews for different products. I bought the DCS-930L because reviews say it works well at night. Now I've come back, I realize many of the reviews are for different cameras. The 930L has an absolutely awful picture in less than bright light. I use mine for surveillance mounted above two bright lights on my driveway. The camera creates awful blue and brown horizontal lines over the whole image and doesn't seem able to auto-adjust to capture low-light images. See my image capture in the user images above. I have a much older D-Link DCS-920 and it is able to operate perfectly in the exact same conditions where this camera fails completely.If you want to use the DCS-930L only during the day in a well lit area, it delivers a great picture and is inexpensive. For 24 hour surveillance, look elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: Expectations Fulfilled
Reviews.Author: Pra "PL"
Reviews.Content: Scenario: Axis M1031W ($250+) has been running for just about 2 years pressed against a window pane giving me a yard view.  Worked fine, nothing spectacular, but started to act up about 2 months ago. Would not stream an image reliably anymore. Contacted Axis, quoted a $98 repair/refurbished fee...began to look at my options.  My requirements were quite modest, 640 x 480 is fine (no megapixel required), good FTP, maybe audio, okay low light (don't need LEDs), remote access. Setup was a breeze, FTP was a bit quirky (needed FTP IP address, not server name) and was up and running.  MyDlink remote access service worked fine initially, but once I switched to my own static IP and port, it stopped connecting....no problem, since I use my own app (TinyCam) to access remotely.  Adjusted settings for image to best available, and at $43 vs $250 new or $98 repair, the winner is this neat little IP camera.  If you look at all the features that Axis provided versus this DCS930L, I'm 90% there and very pleased.

Reviews.Title: It works okay
Reviews.Author: c. lam
Reviews.Content: Bought this to replace my wireless g cams of another brand.  Works as advertised, cost is reasonable.  Image clarity is not great but adequate for my needs.

Reviews.Title: DCS-930L great camera and great support
Reviews.Author: Robin
Reviews.Content: I purchased 6 of these camera and had an initial problem with connecting to my router. I worked with May (ID  AR004630 MAY) who was extremely helpful and informative. Recommend their support when needed.

Reviews.Title: Nice product
Reviews.Author: Richard McCusker
Reviews.Content: I have had no issues with the camera disconnecting from the router.  I have AT&T; DSL and the modem/router I bought from AT&T.;  I used the WPS button to connect three of these cameras to my router.  I unplugged the modem and all three cameras for 8 hours.  I plugged them all back in.  I also reset the modem to factory defaults.  When I accessed the MyDLink account, I could still access all of my cameras.  The quality of the image is low and can't be zoomed in without getting pixelation, but the camera does what I want.  The sound is good and the setup is easy.

Reviews.Title: Tweaked for POE - Works With Blue Iris
Reviews.Author: Kaio
Reviews.Content: This cam ain't half bad. Setup was very easy. If you've set up a Foscam, then you'll have this one going in 5 minutes; if it's your first time, maybe 10 minutes.The night vision IRs get hot fast.  But I've just turned them off.  I'm actually using this outdoors with plenty of lighting, but it does have cover from the elements.  D-Link cams seem to be a tad dark by default, so I also brightened it manually 2 stops.Works with Blue Iris.  Just select the IP settings for a D-Link DCS-900.  No PTZ controls though.  Wanted to be able to adjust the brightness automatically, but nada.  Still happy with it though.*MacGuyver Moment*For those who are adventurous, I was able to tweak this to work with my Wilife Pro 6-PORT POE Power Injector.  The injector itself was a steal at under 20 bucks.  And since the cam was going outdoors, I didn't want to have to run another cable for power.  I already had a network cable run, so I just grabbed a shorter patch cable and an Ethernet adapter to join the 2 cables together.  I cut into the shorter patch cable, then separated the power wires from the Ethernet.  I stripped the Blue + Blue/White and Purple + Purple/White wires, and twisted them together respectively -- one's the positive, the other the negative.  I connected those to an old 2.1mm power connector, and voila, instant POE cable splitter.  Just plug the other end into the POE injector and you've got power and data over the same Ethernet cable.  I figured the wiring was all there anyway, so I may as well tap into the 4 unused wires for power.  Worked like a charm.If you're not adventurous to make your own POE cable, then just buy one of these: AIR802 POEPASS-01 Passive PoE Injector/Splitter with 5.5 mm x 2.1 mm DC Size ConnectorFYI - this IP cam suffers from the same intermittent video glitches as this D-Link PTZ DCS-5020L.  But this 933 also adds some glitchy audio pops.Bottom Line - this is a decent enough IP cam. Compact, light, decent image quality and easy setup.  Plus Blue Iris integration -- Bonus!  Happy! ;oD

Reviews.Title: D-Link Wireless Camera
Reviews.Author: Poppajoe49
Reviews.Content: Bought this because my father in law has dementia and has gone for walks and gotten lost. We have a security system that alerts me when he opens the door, but it doesn't tell me if he comes right back in, or goes for a walk, so I needed something that lets me know if he is in the house or not. This looked like a perfect tool to keep track of him.It couldn't have been easier to set up! All you have to do is follow the directions in the setup CD. Anyone that complained about having trouble setting it up obviously didn't read/follow the directions, because it clearly says:  "CONNECT CAMERA TO YOUR ROUTER"!!!Connecting it to your laptop will not allow it to communicate with the router!It took me about 5 minutes to have it up and working. The picture is clear, the audio is clear, and the website allows you to watch in real time. Make sure to get the My D-Link Lite app for your Android, so you can watch the camera from anywhere. I'm amazed that the website doesn't charge a subscription fee, it's awesome!The 4' power cord is long enough to have it plugged in and set the camera on top of my roll top desk, if you need a longer cord, get a cheap extension cord from Home Depot for $3.I'm going to be ordering another of these to give me another view of inside my house and one of the night vision cameras to watch the front of my house.

Reviews.Title: Good for the price
Reviews.Author: Michael "Tell us about yourself!"
Reviews.Content: Update 4/15/2014I purchased several more of these that were on sale for real cheap (under $50 each) - all were Revision A1 and firmware version 1.03. I upgraded the firmware to the latest on each one, which as of 4/15/2014 is 1.10. All of them work well if connected via the Ethernet connection. Wireless worked great for me so long as I used WEP wireless security, which is what my DLINK router was configured to use. Since I have a number of 802.11n devices now, I decided to change my network from using WEP to WPA since WPA fully exploits 802.11n speed. However, making this change has caused me a lot of grief with the cameras that using wireless. After reconfiguring them to use WPA to match the router, none of the cameras worked & caused the DLINK router to crash. Rather than changing my router back to WEP, I decided instead to disable the wireless feature on the cameras and hook them up to wired Ethernet. This was not a problem for me given where I am placing the cameras near LAN outlets. I have read posts from others complaining about the wireless functionality having issues with this model camera. I am suspecting that maybe it would work fine for WEP but not for WPA.For the cost, I am still happy with the camera as it meets my needs. If I want wireless, I probably will go with a more current model.Original Review:I have a number of these cameras. I have a few around the house to keep an eye on things. They do an ok job. Resolution is about what you'd expect for an IP camera at this price. I have some connected via wired Ethernet, others are wireless. They work ok even at night having my porch light on, so I really don't need the night vision that the nighttime camera provides. Works good with MyLink app. I haven't tried it with the D-View app. I also plan to try it with ManyCam software, but haven't had the time yet. I am also using a couple to keep an eye on a remote location using the MyDlink interface. In that case, the camera is wired to the router and I get decent performance viewing remotely across the internet using Internet Explorer as my browser.All in all, I'm satisfied with the camera for what it does and the price.Dlink Customer support, however, is horrible. I called once and the guy I was talking with seemed clueless on a simple matter I was having with the stand. I eventually figured it out myself, but their tech support was not helpful and seemed dismissive.I've used Dlink products such as Routers and earlier model IP cameras, and have been mostly satisfied.

Reviews.Title: Easy. Good.  Bought a 2nd one
Reviews.Author: Max Rockbin
Reviews.Content: I loved how simple it was to get this set up and working.  I just followed the instructions and it connected to my home wireless network without a hiccup.  The image quality is OK.  Decent for a basic webcam.  Good enough for my purposes.GOOD:Simple to set up and get working.Quality is adequateCheap!Multiple cameras work well.  Just different tabs for different cameras on the web view.iPhone App:  Great!  Also very easy to use. Watching your camera(s) on the iPhone is actually easier a less glitchy than watching on the PC.BAD:Pretty short range for the wireless.  I get better wireless range with my laptop and iPhone (802.11N).  I actually bought a range extender so I could connect a 2nd DCS-930L camera just 40 ft away (but through two walls).Short power cordWeb Viewers are not so great.  The remote web viewer (MyDlink) has resolution issues and Java issues. Works but you have to click an extra OK or two.  And the viewer takes a few seconds to load.  The "local" web view - directly through your own network - also has Java issues - prompting you to authorize the app every time you load it (it doesn't remember the authorization - at least not on my computer which is updated with the latest Java as of 6-8-13). They should really work on this.  Also, it'd be nice if the viewer were more stripped down so you don't have to have a big window open.  Just The Video Please.Not only would I buy this again, but I'd buy a 2nd one.  I've tried to configure other wireless cameras through the firewall, forwarding ports blah blah blah.  Sometimes it works.  Sometimes not.  This one just works.  And it has the nifty smartphone apps. In my book, for the price, that gets it 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: OK video quality
Reviews.Author: Nicholas S. Stees
Reviews.Content: Its just like any other ip webcam, but the video is awfully VGA in nature, it has scan lines that randomly show up, never had a ip camera do that before, but I bought two and they both did it equally. My Foscam and wansview cameras do not do this, but the motion detection did not get a false motion reading from the scan lines so its not a big deal. The D-link web UI is very similar to the D-Link routers UI so its easy to get used to.

Reviews.Title: Simple Security & Smart Surveillance
Reviews.Author: L. J. Oja
Reviews.Content: The first unit took me about 15 minutes to install, and attach to my network.  I found the software difficult to work with because of the recent changes to Java, but once that problem has stabilized, the unit works well.  I have two of these working in a cross fire arrangement, and these two little troopers have been pumping out data to my dlink router.  They are an enormous distance away from the router, yet they both report 90+% signal.  Good little units, and coupled with the attractive pricing, a good acquisition.The other two installed quickly, and work well.  Like anything, the first attempt at anything takes it time.  If you need to use more than one, the minor problems (or hiccups really) with the installation are trivial.  For full operation a Dynamic DNS service needs to be established, and while this might take a bit of time to establish and become acquainted with, this is hardly the fault of the camera.  There is a learning curve to the use of this product, but I am sure that applies to any camera - wired or wireless.I think that when it comes to the picture quality and resolution, there can always be improvements there, but if your needs are average, these will work well in a small retail or home installation.  The instructions for working with a dlink router, and port forwarding are easily followed.  Copying the information to a NAS works well too.I have not tried the email announcement, but will update my review when I do that, but for now, I would recommend this unit or the unit made to replace this particular model.

Reviews.Title: great camera for the price
Reviews.Author: nevadasam "sam"
Reviews.Content: easy set up and for the price you can't go wrong. Its also easy to use and you can set it up to use on your smart phone to get a live picture view any where in the world---tip disconnect your fire wall when setting up this  software

Reviews.Title: EZ setup and works
Reviews.Author: Anil Wortz
Reviews.Content: I did not get the more expensive dlink camera because I did not need the night vision. It would not work for me because I use it to look out the window during the day. It took a few tries to get it to shake hands with my router, but it doesnt break connection anymore. Great value.

Reviews.Title: easy setup but rather fuzzy image
Reviews.Author: N6AC "n6ac"
Reviews.Content: This is our third DCS-93xL camera - setup and utility have been good, even using our Mac computers. There is lots of helpful information at the forumDOTD-Link.

Reviews.Title: Very unstable | D link has the worse support line ever  , do not even think about it
Reviews.Author: Seydou
Reviews.Content: I  have purchase 15 of these units  wchich i install for my cusstomersthe camera after 9 months won't work wirelesslydo not download new firmware for dlinkD link has the worse support line ever  , do not even think about it

Reviews.Title: Tried a lot of different ways but could not connect to my wireless network
Reviews.Author: Hoppaguy
Reviews.Content: I would consider myself somewhat tech savvy so I thought installing this D-link camera would be simple. However, after trying multiple ways and looking online, I still could not connect this camera to my home wireless network. I did give the camera 2 stars since it does have a nice small footprint. Perhaps, I just couldn't figure it out but I would suggest that you be very comfortable with how to configure your wireless router settings before purchasing.

Reviews.Title: Rarely Works
Reviews.Author: R. Golden
Reviews.Content: Camera works about 10% of the time.  I often have to update the firmware or update my version of Java or reboot my router or unplug the camera.  Often, if I do all of those things, it still doesn't work.UPDATE:  In the rare case where I have gotten this camera to work wirelessly, it stops working within a few hours or a day.  Now, I use it only in wired mode which is frustrating because that's not why I bought a wireless camera.  Plus, I had to buy an ethernet powerline adapter so I can use the camera in a different room from my router.Yesterday, I tried accessing my camera remotely and I got a message about a firmware update.  Silly me, I ran the update.  What a mistake.  Now the camera is not working at all, even in wired mode.Meanwhile, my other camera, a Panasonic, works all the time.

Reviews.Title: They have the worst tech support I've ever experienced
Reviews.Author: Charles
Reviews.Content: If you own a Mac, I would suggest not buying this product.  The setup process is entirely different from microsoft set up.  I finally got the camera to work, but needed help configuring it for wireless.  I waited on hold for 30 minutes.  When I finally reached a person, I could not understand him.  He kept talking in circles and trying to get me to update Java to a version that is not support by my operating system.  After 15 minutes of this, I asked to speak to someone else.  He said,"ok" and then never got anybody and just let me wait for another 10 minutes.  The ironic part of this is that two weeks earlier I had set up another of these cameras and I was able to do it with some help.  All I needed was a reminder of a few of the inputs, but they couldn't help me.The bottom line for me is that if you have a product like this in 2012 and it doesn't function with either microsoft or a mac operating system, you should probably get out of the tech business.  A total Mickey Mouse company.  My guess is that they won't be around long.

Reviews.Title: Buggy Software for D-Link DCS-930L Camera and Solutions
Reviews.Author: George H. Conklin
Reviews.Content: The d-link DCS-930L comes with very buggy software.  I have 4 cameras, and each had a different problem!!!  The last two had the same issue, which meant they would not work until new firmware was downloaded.  The process required a phone call to a number listed on a bright orange insert in the instructions.  I was walked through the process by phone.  First, you insert the supplied CD wizard and use it for several steps.  Then you must download a NEW wizard and the new firmware.  You put the firmware on your desktop and unzip it.  Then you put the camera's url into IE, which you found from the first steps before the original wizard crashes (you had better know the url of your router too).  Then you must find the firmware from the desktop and do several steps to download the firmware to the camera.  The DCS-930L must be hard wired into your computer, which also must be hard wired into the internet.  Then you use the new wizard, not the old one.  You also must choose the hard wired option for the camera.  The option for wireless operation in the new wizard does not work.  So you finish up and you have a camera which is hard wired.  To change it wireless, you must go to settings and answer 3 more questions.  You also need the password for your router, after the program finds it.  As for d-link's knowledge pages, I signed up to ask a question but got an e-mail saying you had to "approved."  Forget that...no approval. And the man helping me set the camera up commented, "Most of our users know how to do this."  Right.  Ha. Ha. Ha.  Even the patches are buggy. How would you know that?Getting the e-mail working took several days of fooling around.  I finally found the solution using Bing.  One man said he took 10 hours to get the e-mail working.  I had to set up a gmail account to send the pictures to my usual e-mail.Conclusions:  A whole lot of work for a $59 camera!!!  And the pictures are only so-so.  But they do work. D-Link DCS-930L mydlink-Enabled Wireless-N Network Camera

Reviews.Title: Does not work with Macs - I should have believed all the reviews here!
Reviews.Author: Bellasera
Reviews.Content: This is a typical Windows product, the setup is on a Windows-only CD. You can download a Mac setup in a beta (!) version for OS 10.5 (!) and, of course, it does not work properly. Interesting enough I could get it to work with an Ethernet cable and I could even get it to work with a D-Link own router but never with my Airport station. Customer service is no help.Added on Dec 2012:Their new setup utility does not work with the new Java update (V 7.10). This means you cannot set an area to be monitored and have the camera send an alarm after a movement is detected.This renders the camera worthless for me, it is now just a regular camera for conversations and nothing more.Interestingly enough their own web page mentions that "For security reasons some functions like video settings might not work".Their customer service is extremely bad.

Reviews.Title: fine product after initial set up struggle...
Reviews.Author: yachtsman
Reviews.Content: After over an hour and a half on the phone with customer support & re-reading the instructions I finally got the unit to properly function wireless. This was the most frustrating set up process of any product I've ever experienced. I initially followed the instructions without success. I then called the 800 number and spent over 1 1/2 hours on the phone. I could only get the unit working while plugged into the modem but not wireless. The CS rep was helpful but not the most knowledgeable. He indicated that I had a problem with my log in to my modem. In fact, he gave me the wrong instructions. I needed to check wireless operation & hit the sync button on the modem which I found out the next morning after I gave it one more try before returning it. Once set up, the camera works well & I can now access via my I phone but as noted in previous reviews, the low light use is marginal. The net/net is that you need to be fairly tech savvy to get the unit working wireless but it is a handy low cost remote web cam.

Reviews.Title: Great!...Finally
Reviews.Author: Jim
Reviews.Content: After reading the mix of high and low ratings here I decided to go with this super cheap camera. I'm using it to check in on our pets while we are away. Anyways, like many folks here I ended up having a hassle setting up the wireless component of this camera. Wired worked perfect and was running within minutes. For those of you complaining and blaming your mac or pc and the bundled software, don't, that has nothing to with it. Its a matter of your router's configuration. After trying a multitude of things in my linksys's control panel, I eventually turned off my wifi security and the camera connected immediately, it also worked great on WEP and WPA, but not WPA2(which I had been using)...UNTIL I changed my encryption from "TKIP or AES" to just AES. Upon saving that setting the camera was golden. The Android app is surprisingly good video feed as well, on 3G and at 640x480 resolution. Now that it works I want some more! Which is viable as cheap as these come.

Reviews.Title: GREAT little cam
Reviews.Author: D. Erdman
Reviews.Content: I can not say enough about this cam. I love the fact that I can see my home from anywhere. It works great with my I phone. I now own 5 cameras one of them is an inferred cam that works very well at night. These cams are not weather proof but what I did is set up a few in the inside of my windows to keep an eye on my property. It will also detect movement thru the windows. I can now see what my pets are doing when I away from home. If my house alarm goes off it will call my phone I can now see what's going on (hopefully nothing). The cams are worth the price if you can get it for $70 or less, the inferred for $80 or less. Set up was not hard at all your walked thru it completely.The price goes up and down, just keep checking.

Reviews.Title: Camera works fine - until you upgrade the firmware
Reviews.Author: D. DeGroote "symmetric"
Reviews.Content: I have two of these cameras which worked fine for a year or so.  But last week I needed to change the settings.  I downloaded the app to do this and it told me I had to upgrade the firmware first.  This worked fine for the first camera, but it failed on the second.  It is now totally dead.  D-Link is of no help.  They say it needs to be replaced, but they won't replace it without a receipt, and even if I could find it, it's probably been over a year and out of warranty.  I gave this camera 3 stars because they work, but don't upgrade the firmware or you risk killing and otherwise working product.  Personally I won't be buying any more D-Link products.

Reviews.Title: Good for its price
Reviews.Author: mcgullen
Reviews.Content: I am surprised by the number of negative reviews, which all seem to be from a while ago.  Perhaps DLink has improved the quality of this product?1.  InstallationI followed the quick installation CD.  Because my router as a "WPS" button, I don't even have to connect the camera to the router via a cable.  Apparently the WPS button allows the camera to automatically connect with the router.  Within minutes I was able to view video stream from both mydlink.com and my android phone.The first time I visit mydlink.com, the website told me that my firmware needed an update.  I clicked yes and waited for a few minutes.  Then I could view the video stream with no problem.2.  SettingsSo don't forget to turn up video resolution by visiting the settings page on mydlink.com.  Advanced users can also setup motion detection alerts there.3.  The problemsFirst, the password for the camera itself (not for the mydlink.com account) cannot be longer than 8 digits.  These was not made clear, and caused me some trouble.Second, mydlink.com relies heavily on java applets.  If you fail to see one of the many confirmation prompts for those applets, you will be confused as to why the video "doesn't work."4.  ConclusionGreat product for fewer than $60.  I'd say it has exceeded my expectation.

Reviews.Title: Simplest to set up
Reviews.Author: Cleveland Hts Ed
Reviews.Content: For the money this is a great internet camera. I have tried three brands now, and by far, the DLink internet cameras are the easiest to set up so that you can view the camera remotely on the internet using a laptop or wireless tablet. Both this 930L model and the 932L model set up easily using the supplied CD and instructions. If you want a basic camera that does not cost a lot of money and really is simple (unlike the ones that say they are and really are not!), try this camera. My only regret is that DLink does not make a cost effective outdoor camera with the MyDLink feature or one that pans, tilts, and zooms. Will try mounting one outdoors and see how it works...For night time you obviously need some local light in the room you are viewing for good results, but this is not an issue.I have used these cameras successfully with an ATT Uverse TuWire cable modem and a more traditional DLink wireless router that is connected to a Time Warner Cable cable modem. No port forwarding or other trickly set ups by you is required. DLink handles it all, and, unlike some systems, the DLink service is free.

Reviews.Title: Great value Easy set up.
Reviews.Author: C. mccormick
Reviews.Content: Works with mac and pc. Easy set up. Black and white in low light and color in daylight. Nice size and easy instructions for set up. Can view from iphone or android. Picture is ok in low light and good in daylight.

Reviews.Title: Easy, Simple
Reviews.Author: William G. Schmidt
Reviews.Content: I have two of these cameras and found both easy to set up and use. Having My D-Link is a real plus because you can view the cameras from anywhere you have net access. Their best resolution (640x480) is sufficient for most applications and the built-in microphone is a plus for security work. The included software (D-ViewCam) is robust but difficult to understand. I'd prefer something much simpler. The camera itself, with WiFi and an internal server,is easily moved. I wish D-Link offered a model which was designed for outdoor use (or a cheap enclosure) and I wish the image could have time/date/etc. superimposed on it prior to uploading via FTP. But overall, it's a lot of bang for the buck.

Reviews.Title: Where's the firmware update to get wireless working!?
Reviews.Author: F. Mueller
Reviews.Content: I am a happy owner of the predecessor cameras DCS 920 - after now 2 years they all (we have 4 of them) still work flawlessly in wireless mode. The only thing that I don't like is that they don't have motion detection. I thought that I would be safe to simply order two 930L based on my positive experience with the 920s. Bad choice - as others in the review section say - it is impossible to get them working with some (maybe all) wireless network routers. I set up the camera for wireless use while connected via wire to the router and everything worked fine. As soon as it was disconnected, it failed to hook itself up to the wireless network. There is definitely nothing wrong with the settings, the DCS 920s with very similar browser interfaces have the same settings and work just fine. After six months, I wonder when there is finally a fix for this problem?? I have been a big fan of D-Link but I think I might shop next time somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: Doesn't work well with a external server
Reviews.Author: CoffeeRob
Reviews.Content: We wanted to use this as a wireless weather web cam in our house. After all the reviews I read I though the D-Link web cam could do the job.  First issue was the wireless connectivity. It would connect, but could not get a good signal. So we ran cat-5 ethernet cable to the other side of the house and set up a completely different wireless network. We first tried it 12 feet away and it was 40% percent we were find with that because the ftp working completely fine. It uploaded an image every 30 seconds.  (My mom was really really happy)Then the webcam stopped uploading after about two weeks. So I reset the camera to factory settings and reduced the upload rate to 60 seconds. It also then showed that the wireless was only at 20 percent. So I moved the wireless access point to 5 feet. It was only 5% percent better. So then I tried direct line of sight and 3 feet away and it only gave the signal strength of 35 percent.So I plugged the camera directly into our ethernet cable and that would solve the wireless issue. The FTP would connect but it would not upload the base file name image. It would not upload the base file named image. But it would upload the test image. Sadly the test image would not to the folder I specified but the parent folder of the image I specified.The FTP problems started after almost a month of work properly. I tried a factory reset, I tried every possible setting combination I could. Five years of web design and development and a little problem with a web cam was not going to stop me...I did a few other times and it did work intermittently but it was never reliable beyond half an hour.I phoned the D-Link customer service and that started a 45 minute call of frustration with a fast talking guy with a strong accent who first tried to tell me my poor wireless signal was because my router was only putting out a signal of 35 percent.  But when I told him all other devices were recording 100% strength when they were as close to the router as the camera was. His reply. "I can not comment on your router unless you have a d-link router"Ya that wasn't going to happen, but it's ok we can use the hard wired ethernet cable.The FTP I knew was going to be a hard question and without going into the exhaustive detail that was that frustrating conversation that went around in circles.Q. Do you have the path set.A. YesQ. Can you connect to the FTPA. YesQ. But the test is not going into the right folder?A.  That is correct.Q. You must have set the wrong path.This went around a couple of times. (Like a script or something)Other QuestionsQ. Are you trying to connect to an external networkA. I am trying to connect to a web server. That is what FTP is used for.Q. Maybe try an internal network.A. Why Provide FTP if I can't connect to an external server.Q. I don't know what to tell you sir, but the camera works all the problems you have must be with your network. The camera we have here works perfectly fine.A. Thanks, I will be returning the product.Q. Don't return the camera it works perfectly fine.~~~~~What's worse then a faulty product is the horrible customer service tell me I am doing everything wrong and it works perfectly fine for him.

Reviews.Title: Great camera.  Difficult setup.
Reviews.Author: Charles G.
Reviews.Content: Setup requires a  tech minded person.  Mac version of software setup works but was written by a bonehead.I have several cameras and remote monitoring works great with airport extreame and iPad 3G AT&T;In time, I developed a problem with a poor wifi signal too.  This was was due to a neighbors router being on the same chanels as mine.  After a lot of frustration I called the manufacture of my wifi router (apple).  After the apple care tech told me that apple does not support non apple products, then  he then "suggested" I manually change the wifi Chanel.  I did and the problem was solved.Thank you apple for fixing a d-link camera.

Reviews.Title: Good Unit When its working
Reviews.Author: Jibbie John
Reviews.Content: I bought 2 of these units for my makeshift surveillance camera network. What caught my eye was the web-based feature of viewing your cameras from mydlink.com. Its a lot faster when it comes to recording thanks to the Wireless-N functionality. They work great for daytime surveillance (as long as the sun isn't shining straight on the camera), but becomes useless once darkness rolls in. The DCS-932L is needed for that. I'm not sure well it will work for outdoor use, but its states its good for up to 15ft.I use the D-Link D-ViewCam management software to record daily to a desktop I have connected on the network. It took me a while to fine tune the timing and had occasional issues with the cameras going offline. I plan on reconfiguring the cameras this weekend.
